body.name: History Comics: The Stonewall Riots: Making a Stand for LGBTQ Rights
editorialReviews: Editorial Reviews Review "Engaging account that invites young people to continue to advocate for equality now."―Kirkus"Accessible and intersectional, this compact foray into queer history is an ­essential purchase for all graphic ­nonfiction collections."―School Library Journal, starred review About the Author Archie Bongiovanni is a cartoonist and illustrator living in Minneapolis. Archie has been featured in The New Yorker, The Nib, Vice and Autostraddle. They're the co-creator of A Quick And Easy Guide To They/Them Pronouns, published by Limerence Press, and the graphic novels, Grease Bats, Mimosa, and History Comics: The Stonewall Riots, their collaboration with A. Andrews.A. Andrews (they/them) is a disabled queer writer and illustrator based in Minneapolis, MN. Their debut graphic novel, A Quick and Easy Guide to Sex & Disability (Oni/Limerence Press) has been included in 2020 lists for the NYPL best books for teens, and YALSA’s best books for teens.. They are also the creator of Autostraddle’s Oh, Hey!, a bi-monthly autobiographical comic about being queer, sick, and sometimes embarrassing.

body.description: Turn back the clock with History Comics! In this graphic novel, experience the Stonewall Riots firsthand and meet iconic activists like Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera.Three teenagers―Natalia, Jax, and Rashad―are magically transported from their modern lives to the legendary Stonewall Inn in the summer of 1969. Escorted by Natalia's eccentric abuela (and her pet cockatiel, Rocky), the friends experience the police raid firsthand and are thrown into the infamous riots that made the struggle for LGBTQ rights front-page news. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Great way to learn history
reviews.reviewText: My kids ages 9-12 loved this book. Illustrations were great and it was very informative .

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2022
reviews.reviewText: From my 14 year old who read this book: "This is a book that all teenagers should read as it shows how we can mobilize to fight hate. It's an important, yet sad, chapter in our history."

reviews.reviewTitle: Had never heard of Stonewall Inn
reviews.reviewText: Recommended, as it is informative.The theme covered in this book is not a bump in the road. It is a semipermanent issue.If I had not read the back of the book first, I would not have understood what is happening on pages 9-11, which is the transportation of the characters back in time.
